abstract.text: The pipeline downloads and caches images, and prepares them for display.

inlineContent.text: You can start using a
pipeline and create a custom one later if needed. To create a custom pipeline, you can use a convenience
initializer:
You can customize
by initializing it with
and
. You can provide custom caches, data loaders, add support for new image formats, and more.
The pipeline has two cache layers: memory cache and disk cache. By default, only memory cache is enabled. For caching data persistently, it relies on system
. There are advantages of enabling a custom disk cache. You can learn more in
Use
that works with both
and
and returns an image.

code: let image = try await ImagePipeline.shared.image(for: url)

inlineContent.text: Alternatively, you can create an
and access its
or
to fetch the image. You can use
to cancel the request, change the priority of the running task, and observe its progress.
The recommended way to load images
is by using Async/Await API. But the pipeline also has API that works with closures and Combine publishers.
The pipeline has two cache layers: memory cache and disk cache.

stores images prepared for display in memory. It uses a fraction of available RAM and automatically removes most of the cached images when the app goes to the background or receives a memory pressure warning.
For caching data persistently, by default, Nuke uses
with an increased capacity. One of its advantages is HTTP
support.
You can also replace
with a custom
that ignores HTTP
headers using
is a bit faster than
and provides more control. For example, it can be configured to store processed images using
. The downside is that without HTTP
, the images never get validated and if the URL content changes, the app will continue showing stale data.
To learn more about caching, see
section.
The pipeline avoids doing any duplicated work when loading images. Let’s take two requests with the same URL, but different processors as an example:

code: async let first = pipeline.image(for: ImageRequest(url: url, processors: [
async let second = pipeline.image(for: ImageRequest(url: url, processors: [

inlineContent.text: The pipeline will load the data only once, resize the image once and blur it also only once. There is no duplicated work done. The work only gets canceled when all the registered requests are, and the priority is based on the highest priority of the registered requests.
Coalescing can be disabled using
configuration option.
If progressive decoding is enabled, the pipeline attempts to produce a preview of any image every time a new chunk of data is loaded. See it in action in the

When the pipeline downloads the first chunk of data, it creates an instance of a decoder used for the entire image loading session. When the new chunks are loaded, the pipeline passes them to the decoder. The decoder can either produce a preview or return
if not enough data is downloaded.

Every image preview goes through the same processing and decompression phases as the final images. The main difference is the introduction of backpressure. If one of the stages can’t process the input fast enough, the pipeline waits until the current operation is finished, and only then the next one starts. All outstanding progressive operations are canceled to save processing time when the data is fully downloaded.
